question: That... you don't want to do. Y'all picked the wrong day not to use the ATM. You will not be harmed if you do exactly what I say, when I say it. You No one will say I didn't give you a choice. You, up. You understood what I just said?
answer: Yes.

question: Your security system, you can electronically lock all entrances...
answer: Yes. Right-right away.

question: With that attitude, you and I are going to get along famously. Now go.
answer: It's done. We're locked down.

question: Do you have a warrant?
answer: I need to speak to you, Quentin.

question: There's where your shit out of luck because I don't need to speak to you.
answer: It's important. Quentin, this is Detective Shane Dekker.

question: Charming.
answer: Shane just transferred in from Tacoma. His father...

question: Save your breath. I really don't care. Why don't we can the chit-chat. Get to what's on your mind.
answer: We've got a hostage situation, American National Bank. The sonsabitches said they wouldn't talk to anyone but you.

question: No shit?
answer: No shit. I need you to do this.

question: You may want to put a leash on him. Saying I did want to help... I'm still suspended or did that slip your mind?
answer: The commissioner's office has ordered me to reinstate you. As of now, you're back on the force.

question: Just like that?
answer: Just like that. I won't, however, unleash you alone.

question: Always a catch.
answer: Shane, here, is your new partner. Consider him a younger version of me, looking over your shoulder, watching every move you make. Don't think I endorse this. If it were my call, you'd be with your partner...

question: You mean ex-partner.
answer: ... On the unemployment line with him.

question: For a moment there, I thought you cared.
answer: I care about those innocent people down there. I hope to God someone hasn't made a monumental mistake letting you back in.

question: I'm sure it won't be the last. Get me a line into the bank. Let's see what they really want.
answer: Detective Conners?

question: Who am I speaking with?
answer: For now... You can call me Lorenz.

question: Okay, Lorenz, how are we doing in there? Can we get you anything? Food, medical supplies. We heard an explosion.
answer: Everyone who matters is fine. Of course, I would've preferred not having the authorities involved at all. We weren't planning to be here this long. But, since Seattle's finest needs a presence on the scene, I'm glad it's you.

question: My fame proceeds me.
answer: Don't be flattered. I needed someone who's been through the experience before. Hopefully this time it will go better for all involved. I plan on living a full, long and rich life. I didn't, however, expect them to find you so quickly. I thought you were suspended.

question: I was, but I'm back. You're information's old.
answer: You never get what you pay for. You want to know about the hostages? How many and are they okay?

question: Yes.
answer: Approximately forty, they're fine, considering. All except one. We had a situation.

question: Someone's dead?
answer: Theory... put to practice isn't always perfect. Can't expect to keep the hostages in check if a bad deed goes unpunished or they may... randomly decide to revolt. Chaos... has some order to it. Detective? Are you still with me?

question: What else will I be looking for?
answer: Demands... Probably too much to ask for you and your colleagues to pack up and go home?

question: Safe to say.
answer: Stay by the phone. I'll contact you shortly.

question: Lorenz...
answer: Don't worry, I have no plans until sunrise tomorrow, so hunker down. It's going to be a long one.

question: Wait, we're talking here...
answer: Patience, Detective. We don't want another Pearl Street Bridge, do we?

question: So you're here in his place. Nicotine gum.
answer: You quit smoking?

question: Caffeine, too, if you must know. What? A man's capable of change.
answer: A man, yes. You... I'm not so sure.

question: That's a big call, Quentin. Thought about what you're doing?
answer: You questioning me, Teddy?

question: Unfortunately... yeah.
answer: I question how you can fuck that asshole and still manage to look in the mirror.

question: I'm not going to get into this now. And you're one to talk. I hear...
answer: The hostages are in imminent danger. They've confessed to killing someone, an automatic murder one charge - that's a life sentence, maybe a needle for all of them. So why keep witnesses around to testify? Longer we wait, the greater the risk. We need to go in. Now.

question: I got snipers up top and ten soldiers on the ground.
answer: What's the best way in?

question: Tear gas, blow the doors...
answer: Hold on. No explosives. I got forty civilians in there, too great a chance. Any other way?

question: There's no pussy way in. The doors are locked electronically from the inside. We ain't getting in without force.
answer: What if we cut the power? That will disable the system and we can open the locks manually, come in that way?

question: That'll work.
answer: So we'll take the pussy way, Commander. We cut the power and go in at 11:15 sharp!

question: We're going in!
answer: No. Do not go in. It's a trap!

question: Stand down, Detective. This is my show now.
answer: SONOFABITCH!

question: We let them walk right past us. SHIT!
answer: We got the one Teller dead, the two that were strung up are alive, but in critical condition. A few SWAT incurred 2nd degree burns, but that's the worst of it. Now, depending on who you talk to... there was anywhere from five to nine perps. And nobody got a good look at any of'em, wore their masks the whole time. Dax is rounding up the security tapes now. That should give us a firm number.

question: I want background checks on every hostage. They're all suspects until they're not.
answer: You don't think one of them's still here?

question: Excuse me... I need to listen to the conversation between Lorenz and Conners again?
answer: It'll have to wait.

question: How long?
answer: Hour. Maybe more.

question: Show me how to play it myself?
answer: Look, this isn't how it works. I don't take orders from you. I don't know you and NO ONE touches my stuff. You're going to have to wait. What the hell are you doing?

question: Along with whatever they stole and this war zone they left behind... A man's dead, and the killers are running free. I don't have time to wait. I'll figure it out. Thanks for your help.
answer: Here. This DAT machine. Play, stop, rewind... It's just like using a tape player. Headphones are jacked in. Tape's already inside.

question: What's with this one?
answer: That's the camera in the vault. It blew in the first explosion. That's when you cut the power.

question: So we can't ID them.
answer: There's a four minute, fifty-two second gap, before the image returns. But...

question: They're long gone by then. Go to the head of the tapes, from when they first went in. Document each move they've made for the two hours they were inside.
answer: You got it. Hey... Awful lotta news cameras outside. Maybe one got a look at them coming out?

question: I think this Lorenz was trying to tell us something.
answer: You don't say.

question: The way he spoke... he paused before certain words. Have you ever heard of the Chaos Theory?
answer: What?

question: Edward Lorenz invented the Chaos Theory in the 1960's. It's the study of phenomena that appear random, but in fact have an element of regularity which can be described mathematically.
answer: Try that again?

question: Pretty much... initial state of events may seem unrelated and random, but eventually patterns emerge and in the end all the pieces fit together.
answer: That'll be all. You're a College boy. Which one? Someplace I've heard of or one of those inbred state schools no one's heard of?

question: U Dub.
answer: Not exactly Princeton, but not bad. How did you end up on the force?

question: It's kind of the family business.
answer: Family business? What, your Dad, Dad's Dad and so on and so back?

question: Do we really need all this "get to know you" crap? Couple hours ago you didn't give a shit.
answer: You've grown on me. Besides, I am entrusting my life to you. I should know something about you. I would

question: I know about you, Detective. Everyone does.
answer: You don't say that with much enthusiasm.

question: Not much to be enthusiastic about.
answer: Listen, my reputation often proceeds me. You, however, have no reputation; a fact I need to deal with. After you've been through the shit I have, then you can judge me. Now... we can try to work together, make the best of a bad situation or we can compare Dick sizes all day... Up to you. But since this is your first day here... today... mine's bigger.

question: Listen, my reputation often proceeds me. You, however, have no reputation; a fact I need to deal with. After you've been through the shit I have, then you can judge me. Now... we can try to work together, make the best of a bad situation or we can compare Dick sizes all day... Up to you. But since this is your first day here... today... mine's bigger.
answer: Conners, come in?

question: Go.
answer: Got something you'll want to see.

question: Detectives. Ready for you.
answer: Somebody going on a trip?

question: Looks like it, don't it?
answer: Marnie, you're looking well.

question: Heard you were back, Conners... and keep dreaming. You, on the other hand... I gotta bike myself. Maybe we can go for a ride sometime? Or maybe I can just ride you.
answer: Can we get back to work?

question: We got passports, sun tan lotion, Bermuda shorts, thong bikini, hopefully hers and this...
answer: Must be a fifty large there easy. His cut?

question: You'd think, right?
answer: It's not?

question: Don't put words in my mouth, but... Two things jump out here. First, each bank branch has their own money bands. This is not American National's. After a little checking, it belongs to Pacific Savings of Seattle.
answer: That sounds familiar.

question: It should. Four months ago, a half million dollars was stolen in an armed robbery there. Just a smash-n-grab job. They caught the guys a day later, recovering about $400,000. Those guys have been in lock up since and their trial's still pending. Which leads us to point number two. Do you smell that?
answer: What is it?

question: No reason. Just thinking out loud. When you said it was your "family business" I didn't think... I guess I just didn't connect the dots.
answer: Don't worry about it.

question: Your father was a hero.
answer: Yes he was.

question: At first I thought maybe you were related to the Captain.
answer: No. No relation.

question: The Captain, he just kind of "discovered" you. Through the academy, to excellent evaluation reports, while
answer: Something like that.

question: That's how he found me. Maybe we're not as different as you think. We found the money.
answer: That money was Dwayne's...

question: That money came from our evidence room.
answer: I told you. I don't know nothing about a bank robbery. Whatever Damon was into, I didn't know!

question: So, where were you going?
answer: Vacation.

question: This isn't possession or solicitation, Gina. This is felony-murder one. You could get life.
answer: Me!? I didn't do nothing!

question: It's "I didn't do anything." "Didn't do nothing" is a double negative, infers the positive. The grammar in this country sucks.
answer: Then I didn't do ANY-thing!

question: This isn't going away. You want to walk out of here, you tell me something... now.
answer: I swear I don't know. Now I'm done talking. I want a lawyer.

question: You sure that's what you want?
answer: Yeah.

question: Fine. Then it's two phone calls I'll make. The first will be to the public defender's office. The second to children's services.
answer: What?

question: It's simple... if you insist on a lawyer, I take your kids.
answer: No.

question: Not like you cared about them anyway. You were ready to fly the coop with "Shit-for-brains."
answer: No. You can't do that.

question: I can and I will.
answer: Don't.

question: Tell me what I want to know!
answer: I don't know anything. Please don't take my kids. Please.

question: Get her some coffee... Something hot.
answer: You believe her?

question: I think for the first time in that girl's life she's telling the truth.
answer: You had to know, once she asked for a lawyer anything she told us would have been inadmissable.

question: Who would've known? It would've been my word against hers. Who do you think the jury would've believed?
answer: Justice by any means. Even if you cross the line.

question: Like I said... No one takes anything out of here, unless they sign for it.
answer: So what... He showed you a warrant? What?

question: He must've.
answer: You don't remember?

question: You know how many times someone signs shit in and out? I see the same guys all the time. I can't remember one instance two weeks ago. But if his signature's there, that means he signed for it. Take it up with him!
answer: The money from Richards's place traced back to the Pacific Savings heist a few months ago, a case Callo headed up.

question: Then come and get me you piece of shit. What they told Callo was the plan and what the plan really was may be two different things. Clearly this wasn't part of a plan Callo would've agreed with.
answer: You'd think a cop would be smarter.

question: As cops we come across every temptation in the book. Money, drugs, power. We'd all like to think we can resist any urge, but... We're not saints.
answer: So, Callo was involved and now they're dragging you into it. Why?

question: Man said he wanted vengeance.
answer: Piss anyone off lately?

question: You like Italian?
answer: Detective, where you been? Much too long. Sit, sit. I give you best table in house. It'll just be the two?

question: No, four. More are coming.
answer: Wonderful, wonderful. Who's this young man?

question: For all intents and purposes... he's Big Brother.
answer: He's your brother?

question: No.
answer: No matter, no matter... I bring you bottle of house wine!

question: No wine?
answer: A little wine.

question: That's better.
answer: Last time I was here, you said that table in the corner was the "best in the house."

question: It was. Anywhere you sit becomes best table in house. Now relax, I bring you food.
answer: Shane, what was that thing you said back at the house about "returning to the beginning path" or something?

question: No. Just something I picked up along the way.
answer: But you're religious?

question: Not particularly. You're all pretty tight.
answer: We've been through a lot together.

question: It's too late. You've made your choice. Live with it.
answer: We got a match.

question: You got a name?
answer: Chris Lei.

question: Sonofabitch. Prick used to work for some big-time software company until they caught him dipping into the company's slush fund. They didn't want the publicity so they didn't press charges. Couple years later, he was busted for looting the pension plans of retired cops. For a genius... he's a fucking moron.
answer: This was your case. You and York. You made the bust. Why didn't it stick?

question: His lawyer put us on trial. Said we were crooked, abusive, that we planted evidence... We were in the midst of the Pearl Street Bridge fallout. Jury bought it. They let him walk and we were the scapegoats.
answer: Was it true?

question: The guy was guilty. He was scum. That was the truth. There's something they don't teach you. The system breaks down. You have to compensate to get results.
answer: That gives you the right to break the rules?

question: Break, no. Bend... if it means justice... Absolutely.
answer: Another thing they don't teach you.

question: You okay?
answer: Yeah.

question: First day in the city and you've already been shot.
answer: Why don't I "just graze" you with a bullet and see how you feel.

question: Take five, guys. Hiya, Damon. How you feeling?
answer: May I? You remember me, don't you? Thought so. I was skiing about three years ago. Aspen. Beautiful country. Ever been? Never mind. I hit a mogul, landed on a sheet of ice and slammed into a tree. Broke myself up pretty bad. Kinda like you did today. I was in a hospital bed for three months. Had it not been for... Here it is. Morphine. Without this stuff, I wouldn't have made it. Now this IV drip administers a small dosage every minute. Makes you feel relaxed and calm. No pain. But... If I were to inject this whole thing... That would be all she wrote for Damon. This equipment malfunctions all the time. Overdoses are quite common. Besides, I don't think the DA's going to launch a full-scale investigation over a scum like you. You don't have to tell us a damn thing. Plead the fifth... roll the dice.

question: You fuckin' hypocrite. You give me shit for my interrogating skills... least I don't threaten them with a lethal overdose.
answer: There's never been a single case in recorded medical history of someone overdosing on 200 milliliters of saline. Bend, not break. That's what you said, right?

question: You never think of the repercussions. The suspect's mother, father... Brother. How your decision affects them. He had murder in his eyes.
answer: John Curtis.

question: It was pouring. Lights everywhere. If he had only done what I said. Drop the weapon. But it was not to be.
answer: My father died when I was twelve. He walked into a liquor store in the middle of a stick up. Guy just opened fire. Never even had time to react. They said he was a hero. Know what

question: So why become a cop?
answer: Finish what he started. Every day he went out, trying to do some good. Help the people who couldn't help themselves, just give'em a chance is what he always said. Didn't always work out right, but he tried. You tried to help save that girl on the bridge. If you weren't there, the girl still would've died. She had a chance because you were there. That's all we can do.

question: We go now all we get is Galt and Harrington. We want Curtis. Now relax and keep the line free. Shit.
answer: What?

question: We hold. No one move. No. Stand down.
answer: We're going to lose'em, Conners.

question: No. No go. We wait.
answer: We bust them now, we got something. But if they get in that car we don't have jack squat.

question: Gas. Get out of here! Get out of here NOW!
answer: Conners!

question: Everyone get down!
answer: Where's Conners?

question: No! No, we have to go save him!
answer: We can't.

question: We have to.
answer: Teddy...

question: No!
answer: ... If it had to be someone...

question: You sonofabitch.
answer: Teddy...

question: You've always been jealous of him.
answer: Jealous?

question: It's because he wasn't only a better cop... He was a better man.
answer: Detective. Go home. You have something you want to say?

question: No, Captain. She said it perfectly.
answer: Detective Galloway, could you give us a comment? We just wanted a statement.

question: Shame on you.
answer: This is more than just news for us. American National's CFO sits on the Board of Channel Two. They have a vested interest in what's going on.

question: Detective? I know what they were doing inside the bank. These are today's transaction records from the bank. An average day produces about 400 pages, give or take. Today, there were over 3,000 pages.
answer: Meaning?

question: We've just witnessed the largest heist in history. Somewhere in the neighborhood of a billion dollars.
answer: Come again?

question: It's a computer virus. "The Computer Virus." It randomly withdraws money from all the accounts and deposits it into the bad guys' account. If you check the transactions, no two withdrawal amounts are the same and none of'em are over $100. Most security systems work on the size of the money, not number of transactions. Wire out one million from a handful of accounts and red flags go up. Wire out a less than a hundred from ten million accounts, no flags.
answer: Where's the money now?

question: I tried following one of the transactions. It took me an hour and when I finally had it... It went away.
answer: How is that possible?

question: The virus created a host of phantom accounts where the money goes
answer: It's still moving the money around?

question: Yeah. Any deposit or withdrawal from any bank doesn't usually go into affect until the next business day. So it's going to keep jumping around until it clears at 9 AM tomorrow.
answer: Or 6 AM Pacific time. Sunrise. So why break in? If they're just wiring money? Couldn't they do that from anywhere?

question: That's the regional manager's computer terminal. There's no outside/remote access to it. There you have unlimited entry to the bank's mainframe. No passwords to work around, no "hacking" in. It's all nice and clean.
answer: A billion dollars is missing and we're only discovering this now?

question: Ironically, when the power went out, it helped hide the virus and bought it time to work.
answer: So they weren't trying to make it look like they were robbing a bank, to rip off a Saudi Prince? They were making it look like they ripped off a Saudi Prince to rob a bank. The Chaos Theory. Dekker. Put it through. It's not over yet. No. My wish is to catch you. You're a murderer. A cop killer at that. I know about the money. You steal a billion dollars... They will find you.

question: So they weren't trying to make it look like they were robbing a bank, to rip off a Saudi Prince? They were making it look like they ripped off a Saudi Prince to rob a bank. The Chaos Theory. Dekker. Put it through. It's not over yet. No. My wish is to catch you. You're a murderer. A cop killer at that. I know about the money. You steal a billion dollars... They will find you.
answer: You're still here?

question: Callo's insignificant.
answer: What?

question: That's what he said, Callo's insignificant. But he wasn't.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Lorenz... Curtis... Called me.
answer: He called you?

question: He said he didn't kill anyone who didn't deserve it. He said Callo was insignificant. But without Callo he wouldn't have had the knowledge of our department and... ... He wouldn't have had the front money to hire the crew.
answer: He was screwing with your head. Go home, Shane. You did good today. Your Dad would be proud. Get some sleep. There will be more bad guys tomorrow.

question: I was in bed already. This couldn't wait til morning.
answer: How did he come at you, Harry? It's the only thing that doesn't make sense.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: All day long we thought Callo was the dirty cop. All day long we were wrong. That's the sign-out sheet from the evidence room. Here's one of Callo's reports. Here's another one... and another -- They're not the same signature, Harry. They're not even close.

question: Maybe he had a cramp in his hand. I don't know.
answer: This is your file... You were reprimanded, a month ago after you confronted Callo at the courthouse. You punched him. That ring a bell?

question: And I'd do it again. Cops who testify against cops shouldn't be breathing the same air I do. There's a line you don't cross!
answer: So you set him up! You forged Callo's signature, you gave him the money and you helped him with his plan because you thought he got a raw deal at Pearl Street Bridge! Don't deny it, Harry cause I know. You're helping a cop killer, Harry. You're a year from pension. This is how you want to go out?

question: My conscience is clean.
answer: This has been a very long, trying day. And I'm tired. We're chasing a

question: Of course he has. Who knows Conners better than him?
answer: How the hell does Curtis know Conners better than anyone? We're not talking about Curtis, are we, Harry? Who would know Conners better than anyone? Who would you protect? And who in your mind got the raw deal at Pearl Street Bridge?

question: Watch me.
answer: The number York used to call Harry Hume is a cellphone number. Ran it through

question: Can they get a location on him?
answer: That particular phone he's using is equipped with the latest GPS technology. Should be able to trace his location within 100 meters or less. Yeah? They got him. The signal's coming from around 175th street. That's about fifteen miles north of us. From the harbor he can take a boat or a sea-plane out. He's gone.

question: No. If there's a signal. Means he's still here. He's waiting for something or someone.
answer: Waiting? Where? Ain't nothing down there that's open at this hour.

question: Keep the change.
answer: Jason York... this is the police. Put your hands in the air and slowly get on your knees. Do it. Now!

question: Don't shoot. You win.
answer: Get down on the pavement!

question: I'm cooperating. You win.
answer: GET DOWN NOW! FINAL WARNING!

question: I SAID... I... GIVE... UP!
answer: Take the back!

question: Was it Harry? It was Harry, right? That fat fuck!
answer: Let the girl go. It's over.

question: Easy for you to say. I'm a plane ride away from a King's Ransom.
answer: Drop the weapon, let the girl go.

question: And spend the rest of my days in a cage? Let me ponder... Don't think so. If you're going to stop me... I'm gonna make you earn it.
answer: That you don't want to do.

question: That's exactly what I said to him. Do you see the irony here? Am I the only one? Two months ago I was in your shoes. Some punk holding a gun to an innocent girl. What should you do? YOU'D DO EXACTLY WHAT I DID!
answer: Shit.

question: We used to spend all day Sunday just reading in bed. I would read the paper and he would read one of his billion books. I didn't deserve him. I knew that. But I still loved him. He's the only man I ever loved. Did we all get shot today?
answer: They said in the city I'd be busy. Every day like this?

question: Pretty much.
answer: Great. I wonder what's next?

question: For me... a long vacation.
answer: How much? Thanks.

question: How much? Thanks.
answer: Do you smell that?

question: What is it?
answer: When evidence is taken in, any physical mark might effect the ability to lift prints, so, to mark it, we spray it with a scented solution.

question: You tried them all?/ Nothing for Conners or Lorenz?/ I don't know. No, maybe he's not on a flight. Try again. But try Gleick. James Gleick.
answer: There's a passage in the Surangama Sutra which, roughly translated means

question: Conners?
answer: Think about that a minute... Doesn't that blow your mind? What gave me away?

question: Ten bucks.
answer: At the diner. That's right... Well, to err is human. Was it Harry that gave him up?

question: Harry and the phone call. He called me, said Callo was insignificant. Threw up a red flag.
answer: That wasn't him. That was my mistake. I called you. I didn't kill anyone who didn't deserve it. York always thought "the plan" was flawless. He was cocky. I told him you have to leave room for error. You can't always predict how it's all going to play out. A random camera catches an image of Richards, the scent on the money... you. You were the biggest wrench of the day. The Chaos Theory... When you got that... I was impressed.

question: All day long, we were trying to find out who the inside source was... it was you.
answer: The more information you gather, from as many sources as possible, no matter how unpleasant the methods are, the better. And while I'd like to take sole credit it was a team effort.

question: Teddy's pretty devastated about your death.
answer: She'll get over it.
